Frontiers in Cancer Genomics" course. Its an exciting new area that has lots of exciting

things happening and your gonna learn

really, really important disease. 50% of
man and 33% of women will get

cancer at some point in their lifetime.
We need better ways of diagnosing cancer

and we also very sorely need better
treatments. Cancer is a genetic disease.

Almost all cancers are the results of
multiple mutations. Cancer is also a

genomic disease in that every cancer cell
has a unique collection of changes that

cause cells to grow uncontrollably. If we
really want understanding cancer, and

also treat cancer, we have to look very
carefully at the DNA of their cancer.

What we're gonna learn in this class is the
difference between inherited and

sporadic cancers, or inherited cancers;
the familiar cancers, the kind that run

in families. We're also going to learn
about classifying cancers based on the

genome differences, not just where they
come from. Very importantly, you're going to

understand how cancer cells evolved to
become resistant to treatment. There's a

number of community initiatives for
enhancing cancer research and

understanding how cancer cures. And

cool primary research that's occurring
in the cancer field and some of the

exciting developments that are going on.
And certainly you're going to hear about
